reviewText: Ten years ago, acting on pure whim, I bought the Petey Wheatstraw DVD at a video store in Rochester, NY. I watched it that same night, and hated it. "What a cheapo hunk-of-junk movie," I thought at the time. Then, something odd happened. I moved away from Rochester, and pawned many DVDs in the process...but not Petey Wheatstraw. The film was just too memorable for me to part with it. I reluctantly came to the conclusion that I kinda liked it.A decade later, I still own this stupid thing. And over time I've grown to love it, without reservation. :-)Even a mere plot summary is enough to remind me of why it's great. Simply put: Petey, the hero, is a stand-up comedian and kung fu master who is killed by agents of a rival comedy team in a drive-by shooting. But Lucifer offers to resurrect Petey and give him magic powers with which to take his revenge - provided that Petey agrees to marry "Lou's" ugly daughter. Petey takes the deal, but he has no intention of honoring his side of the bargain...In short, this film creates it own bizarre and hypnotic universe, in which comedians control powerful gangs and devils roam the city streets in bright pink-and-white tights. It's, like, awesome. Perhaps my favorite part is Lucifer himself, who is not depicted as just some horrible villain. In this movie, the Devil truly loves his daughter, thoroughly enjoys jogging (in a flame-red track suit, naturally), and generously throws Petey a bachelor party involving beautiful demon women. (Yes, it's *that* sort of movie, where literally anything can happen!)Right, enough of me waxing poetic. I guess you want to know how the DVD is? Well, it's old now, but the menu design holds up surprisingly well. The print is not great (but presumably it never was?) And the special features are pretty spartan; you get a badly filmed location tour with Rudy Ray Moore, some stupid trivia questions (most of which apply to Dolomite instead), and some hilarious trailers for other Moore films (but not this one). Still, you can tell that some effort went into it all.Really, the best thing on the DVD is the movie itself. It delivers! And it's great! Sort of. Watch it yourself, and thank me later...
